title: How to Make an Edible Advent Calendar

steps.headline: Preheat your oven to 355°F (180°C).
Cut the butter into the flour, baking powder, and ground ginger.
steps.description: Combine the dry ingredients in a large bowl first, then cut the butter into them. You can use a food processor, pastry blender, or two crisscrossing knives for this step. For chocolate gingerbread, add ½ cup 50 grams) of cocoa powder.

steps.headline: Mix together the brown sugar, egg, and golden syrup in a separate bowl.
steps.description: Place the brown sugar into a clean mixing bowl, then add the egg and brown syrup. Stir everything together until evenly combined.

steps.headline: Pour the egg mixture into the flour mixture, and mix until a dough forms.
steps.description: Start by stirring everything together with a spoon or rubber spatula. Once it is just combined, use your hands to finish kneading the dough. The dough may be dry at first, but it will eventually soften up. If the dough is too dry, add a splash of milk.

steps.headline: Chill the dough in the fridge for 30 minutes.
steps.description: Wrap the dough in plastic wrap, then put it into the fridge for 30 minutes. This will prevent the dough from becoming too mushy when you roll it out.

steps.headline: Roll the dough out on a sheet of parchment paper, then cut it into shapes using cookie cutters.
steps.description: You can use standard sized cookie cutters or mini cookie cutters. You will need 25 cookies, one for each day on the Advent Calendar. They can be Christian symbols, such as stars and angels, or they can be holiday symbols, such as trees, reindeer, and stockings. Consider making a larger cookie for the last day on the Calendar. It might be a good idea to make a few extra cookies in case you mess up. If you plan on hanging the cookies, use a straw or skewer to poke holes into the top of each one.

steps.headline: Peel away the excess cookie dough, then lift the parchment paper and place it onto a large baking sheet.
steps.description: Once you have cut out as many shapes as you can fit, peel the excess dough away and ball it up. Lift the parchment paper up and place it on a large baking sheet.

steps.headline: Chill the dough for another 30 minutes.
steps.description: Place the entire baking sheet back into the fridge, and leave it there for 30 minutes. This will prevent the cookies from spreading and losing their shape when baked.

steps.headline: Bake the cookies for 12 to 15 minutes, or until firm.
steps.description: It is better to over-bake these cookies than to under-bake them. You will be using them as an Advent Calendar by eating one each day; you want them to last the entire month.

steps.headline: Allow the cookies to cool completely before decorating them.
steps.description: Once the cookies are baked, transfer them to a wire cooling rack, and let them cool. This will take about 5 minutes.

steps.headline: Beat the egg white and vanilla extract until they turn frothy.
steps.description: Separate the egg yolk from the white. Save the yolk for another recipe, and put the white into a large bowl. Add the lemon juice, then beat until the whites turn frothy. You can do this using a stand mixer, a handheld beater, or a food processor fitted with whisks. If you'd prefer something less sweet, use lemon juice instead of vanilla extract. Be sure to use pasteurized egg whites.

steps.headline: Add the confectioner's sugar gradually.
steps.description: Turn the speed down to the lowest setting and add the sugar slowly. Keep beating until the sugar is evenly mixed in. The mixture should look a little shiny at this point.

steps.headline: Beat the mixture on high speed until it forms stiff peaks.
steps.description: This will take about 5 to 7 minutes.

steps.headline: Divide the icing into bowls, and stir in some food coloring into each one.
steps.description: You can use as many colors as you'd like, or just two different ones. For a more old-fashioned look, consider leaving one of the bowls white. You can use as much or as little as you'd like. The more food coloring you use, the darker and more vibrant the color will be. One color will be your background color. The other color will be your detail color. Plan on using more icing for the background.

steps.headline: Put the icing into piping bags fitted with a size 0 piping tips.
steps.description: If you have any icing left over, cover it with plastic wrap, and put it into the fridge.

steps.headline: Outline your cookies, then let the icing dry for 10 to 30 minutes.
steps.description: Choose a background color, then pipe the icing around the inside edges of your cookies. This will create a border for the icing, and prevent it from running off. Once you have the cookies outlined, let them dry for 10 to 30 minutes. If you added holes to your cookies, be sure to outline around the hole. This way, you won't risk accidentally filling it in.

steps.headline: Squeeze the icing back into the bowl, and add some water to thin it out.
steps.description: Using the same color as you did for the piped edges, squeeze the icing back into its bowl. Stir in some water so that it becomes thinner. You'll be using this to fill in your outlines.

steps.headline: Fill in your outlines using the thinned icing.
steps.description: Some people find that using a skewer or cocktail stick helps them guide the icing to the edges. You want the icing to blend in smoothly with the outlines.

steps.headline: Allow the icing to dry completely, or until it is hard.
steps.description: This can take up to 12 hours. Be sure to store your piping bags in the fridge so that they don't dry out.

steps.headline: Write numbers on the cookies.
steps.description: Take out your piping bags, and write a number on each cookie. An Advent Calendar has 25 days, so number the cookies accordingly. Consider writing 25 on the largest cookie.

steps.headline: Decorate the cookies further, if desired.
steps.description: At this point, your cookies are done, but you can still decorate them further. For example, if you have stocking-shaped cookies, you might want to add the trim. If you have gingerbread men-shaped cookies, you might want to add the face.

steps.headline: Let the icing dry completely before using them.
steps.description: If you added holes to them, cut some ribbon, and thread it through each hole. Hang the cookies on a decorative board or on a tree. If you did not add holes, you can put them into a banner with 25 pouches, or into a box with 25 slots.
